section.title: Past simple and continuous
section.sectiontitle:
We use the Past simple (verb + -ed) for completed actions and states in the past.
We often say when the action or state happened. Many verbs are irregular.
section.text2a: We stayed in Saudi Arabia for a month last year.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use did + not + verb and in the question, we use did + subject + verb.

section.title: Past simple and continuous
section.sectiontitle: We use the Past continuous (was/were + verb + -ing) for actions in progress at a time in the past.
section.text1a: I was having breakfast at eight o'clock.
section.text2a: I heard the news while I was driving home.
section.sectiontitle2:
We often use the Past continuous to describe the situation or background to a story and the Past simple for the main events or actions. We use when or while
to link them.
section.text3a: I met Linda while I was living in Spain.
section.text4a: We were having breakfast when the phone rang and I answered it. It was Paul.

section.title: Past simple and continuous
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use was/were + not + verb + -ing. In the question, we use was/were + subject + verb + -ing.
section.text1: He was driving the car that night.
section.text1a: He wasn't driving the car that night.
section.text2a: Were you living in Canada then? Yes, I was.
section.sectiontitle2:
We do not use the Past continuous with state verbs such as love, like, hate,
want, know, believe, understand, cost, belong, etc.
section.text3a: I hated vegetables when I was young.
section.text4a: I didn't know much about India when I first went there.
